utterances: (Soundbite of ""The Show"")
When I come out of the bullpen, round and out, it's a rush and your adrenaline starts pumping.
Everybody's looking at you, the (unintelligible) who's coming to the game.

Former starting pitcher, now in the bullpen for Tucson, Murphy had himself a tremendous Arizona ball league and now the Diamondbacks will count on him to be a key member of the pen this year here in Tucson.
Murphy joins us now by phone from his hotel in Nashville, Tennessee.
Nice to have you on the program today.
Thanks Neal.
Thanks for having me.
And I know you're one of the players featured - what was it like having cameras following you around all the time?
You know, it was just - it's weird, you know, not for us but for - pretty much, every in the clubhouse.
I mean, you know, sometimes, you know, guys like to, you know, the clubhouse is a personal place for a lot of guys, you know, hangout and - you know, it was fun.
You know, it's about two weeks of nonstop footage so it's pretty cool.
And I don't want to rundown the glamour but it's not all that often that television cameras show up in triple-A clubhouses.
No, it's not too often.
I mean, sure when you're in a race to win the division, you might get a, you know, a local news come out there and shoot you a little bit but nothing like that.
There are other occasions earlier this year in a rehabilitation assignment, Randy Johnson, the future of Hall of Famer, a pitcher for the Arizona Diamondbacks, he's on the same pitching staff as you?

Yeah, it was, you know, that was really exciting because you go on up, you know, Randy, I used to watch him on TV all the time and you know, even seen him in camp and spring training was, you know, shocker and to have him come down throw for us, you know, he puts some fastest stance for us and it was fun to watch him pitch.
And is - he's got a reputation as being a - well, at least, on game day, a little surly to approach.
Did he live up to his reputation?
You know what, he was awesome.
He came in, you know, talked to everybody, you know, obviously, you know, you don't want to let the guy get his work done so you try to stay away but, you know, he helped out some guys.
You know I know I pitch staff from one ballgame and came in and talked to him a little bit and that's what he felt.

And he asked me how I felt and, you know, we're both going through the same thing - if we are early in the season, you know, you kind of, after spring training, you got those long innings, you know, you're really don't get to pitch much and then, you know, beginnings seems, kind of, like an extension of spring training for a lot of guys so.
You know, it's just neat to watch him and - even have the chance to talk to him.
Earlier in the program, we played a clip of tape of you talking about the numbers game that every time somebody gets promoted and achieves their dreams, somebody else is off the team.

Yeah, you know, it's tough because I remember when I, you know, I was - there's a clip in the ""The Show"" were I was in Vancouver, you know, and we had a bunch of guys that you're nine - nine guys picking up the first three rounds of the Oakland.
We all came to Vancouver when we saw some guys get released and you know, we didn't know what was going on.
You know, there's only - there's not one too many levels below short seasons so it was a tough shot but it's part of the game.
And some of those players go on and, well, even scuffle along in the independent leagues for a while, try to make it back.
You can be one of the 2,000 best ballplayers of the world and not have a job in professional baseball.
Yeah, you know, it's a day-to-day game.
You know, we had a young kid named Justin Upton, double A.
I mean, he swings the bat really well.

I mean, he's only 19 years old and, you know, he has get his chance because I mean, the numbers he's putting up, you know, he can be a triple-A any day now so, he can even go to Baileys like Mark Reynolds.
So injuries happen, stuff happens so, you know, you're always looking behind you, you always want to keep looking forward.
And I understand, you're about on your way out of the hotel, getting ready to leave for the ballpark?
Yeah, we're national.
We have a 3:00 bus that go to the park.
We stretch about 4:00 so we get there a little early and get ready.
Yeah, hang around the clubhouse and what, play spades?
Yeah, well, we play a little hearts today, you know, (unintelligible) in the clubhouse, playing hearts, the only game he plays so.
And then Randy Choate, you know, he's a stickler for hearts.
He likes to give me the queen of spades all the time which is very nice.
Mm-hmm.
Randy Choate, of course, played in the big leagues for the Yankees among other teams.
And when you talk to guys like that, you say - I've seen your numbers this year, your areas are very good, many if you were hits than innings pitch which is also very good.
So are you saying - looking around up with the big league and saying when do I get my chance?
You know, you always think that but you know, you still got to come here and pitch here because if you start worrying about other things that affects you on the mound.
And it shows, you know, Randy has talked to me quite a few times.
He's sent me some nice text messages when he was at the Twins there in the spring training, you know.
And it's emotional but you just got to stay positive.
And what about your family because it's pretty tough if you have a girlfriend or a wife?
Yeah.

You know, I have a girlfriend, her name is Natalie(ph) Phoenix with me and, you know, it's tough on her but you know, she's really strong, she supports me and everything and I really appreciate that and my family, I mean, my mom and my dad used to come to every game when I was in college and high school.
Now, it's hardly ever getting to see them instead of the Phoenix now so it's real tough on them.
My mom is always giving me crap but, you know, they understand.
They know I'm chasing a dream and they support me 100 percent.
And if you never make it, it's still all right?

You know, I've gave up my all, you know, I've trying hard, you know, and there was always room out there for left-hand pitchers So, I'm going to, you know, keep going until someone says can't play anymore.
Murphy, good luck.
I appreciate, Neal.
Thanks for having me.
Bill Murphy, a pitcher for the Arizona - for the Tucson Sidewinders with us today by phone from his hotel.
He's on the road in Nashville, Tennessee.
Still with us is Rick Parr.
He's the general manager of the Tucson Sidewinders.
Let's see if we get another caller on the line.
This is Frank.
Frank's calling us from Buffalo, New York.

I would like to hear what your guest has to say about the opportunity for advancement for players who get different signing bonuses, players who don't have as much invested in - cannot buy the team, as the so-called bonus babies that are drafted into the higher rounds.
What's like - or is there an equal opportunity for advancement based on performance?
How much of it is strict meritocracy, Rick Parr?
Yeah, I think, that's a legitimate question.
I can tell you this, it's more about high profile.

What they do with the bonus babies is they will watch them meticulously and that's okay because that's the way it should be, you paid a lot of money for these guys and you want to - you are very, very interested in seeing your investment come to maturity.
So what we look at here is but do not underestimate the guy that is putting up statistical numbers.
You know, the guy that, you know, let's take a Murphy who's just was on.
Yeah.
I can just tell you that if you don't think that they know exactly what Murphy does, they do.

And if you don't think they don't what Dustin Nippert is doing, and I'm going to conclude my little thoughts on Dustin here in a few minutes but I will tell you this, right now, Dustin Nippert was not a bonus baby at all.
He is so close to the major leagues.
You know, he can do more than taste it, he believes he's there.
So I would be - I'm not surprised that if I can get a phone call within the next two weeks that Dustin Nippert's gone and he's the next guy up.
Now, he again, he wasn't a bonus baby.
But he is putting up so many great numbers and when you see him pitch at the ballpark, you ask yourself, what is he doing on this team.
He used to be in a big leagues.

But wouldn't you be - wouldn't you agree with Frank that players sign the big contracts, the bonus babies, get a better opportunity particularly in the lower rungs but after a few years, the numbers don't lie.
No, they don't.
And what they do is they really, you know, they look at those guys - don't kid yourself, they look at them - but they look at all of them.
Nowadays, they have this thing down to a science.
And if you do anything good, you don't have to be a bonus baby and you'll still make it through the show.
All right, Frank, thanks for the call.
Can I ask one more thing real quick?
Real quick.

The disparity of money between the majors and minors, you know, a guy like Alex Rodriguez make $25 million a year, does any of that money - are these players - do they send it (unintelligible) back for the minors, do they share at all?
Does that ever happen?
You know, that is a really, really good question.
No, they don't.
There's no share.
There's no money in it whatsoever.

The minor leagues are the minor leagues are totally separate: the unions that are at the major league level and is non-union at the minor league level, and the minor leaguers will never share in that money that Rodriguez makes.
And so what is the typical minor leaguer in triple-A make?
You know, I'm guessing right around $1,750 a month.
That'sâ€¦
That's just for the six months of the season.
That's for six months.
And, you know, it's not much.
But you know, it does make them want it and they want it more, and it's a good thing, not a negative thing at all.
Frank, thanks for the call.
Let's see if we can get Pam on the line.
Pam's with us from Marietta, Ohio.
